The Numbers

Blackpool Council's spending data reveals £4.1 billion in external payments across 630,914 transactions with 9,846 unique suppliers spanning April 2019 to January 2026 — nearly seven years of financial data and the second-largest dataset on the AI DOGE platform.

As a unitary authority, Blackpool handles both district and county-level functions: housing, planning, and waste collection alongside education, social care, highways, and fire services. Its annual budget of approximately £480 million reflects this combined responsibility.

Where the Money Goes

Supplier concentration at Blackpool is low, with an HHI of 77.0 and the top five suppliers accounting for 14.4% of total expenditure. This is consistent with a large unitary authority managing hundreds of care providers, contractors, and service suppliers across the full range of local government functions.

The breadth of services — from children's social care placements to seafront maintenance — naturally distributes spending across a wide supplier base.

Red Flags in the Data

Blackpool's automated DOGE analysis returned a fraud triangle score of 68.2 out of 100 — above average and indicative of several areas requiring attention:

  • £217,700 in likely duplicate payments — relatively modest for a dataset of this size, suggesting reasonable payment controls
  • £198.3 million in suspected split payments — transactions structured below approval thresholds
  • £342.5 million in round-number payments over £5,000 across 5,331 transactions — a high proportion that may indicate estimated rather than invoiced amounts

The round-number figure is particularly notable. While some round payments are legitimate (grant allocations, fixed-fee contracts), £342.5 million in round-figure payments across 5,331 transactions warrants scrutiny. Round numbers are a recognised indicator of estimated rather than verified payments.

Political Context

Blackpool Council is controlled by Labour. As one of the most deprived local authority areas in England — consistently ranking at or near the bottom of the Index of Multiple Deprivation — the council faces acute demand pressures on social care, housing, and public health services. This deprivation context is critical when assessing spending patterns: high social care expenditure is a function of need, not necessarily waste.

Data Quality

With nearly seven years of data and 630,914 transactions, Blackpool provides one of the most comprehensive spending records of any council on the platform. The long time series enables meaningful trend analysis across pre-COVID, COVID, and post-COVID periods.

Explore the full dataset on our Spending page, or see our DOGE Investigation for deeper analysis.
